title: Tuesday, 10th November, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

PM

11:01 am
PM

PM

Liu Yiqian

PM

Chinese "billionaire

11:02 am

PM

PM

Since he's just spent $170m on this...

11:02 am

PM

Modigliani's reclining Nude

PM

I love Modigliani

11:04 am
PM

Anyway, it seems Liu first came to prominence in the West after buying a 500 year old "chicken cup" and promptly drinking tea out of it

PM

They are regarded as the holy grail of Chinese porcelain and only a handful of them remain; almost all of them carefully guarded in the world’s most important museums.

But after spending more than $38 million (HK$281.24 million) to buy a Chenghua Meiyintang “chicken cup,” Liu Yiqian decided to put it to immediate use. “It happened when I was paying,” the Shanghainese billionaire told the Wall Street Journal.

“A Sotheby’s staffer poured me some tea. I saw the [chicken cup] and excitedly poured some of that tea into the cup and drank a little. Such a simple thing, what is so crazy about that?”

“Emperor Qianlong has used it, now I’ve used it,” he added, referring to the Qing Dynasty emperor. “I just wanted to see how it felt.”

PM

http://news.nation...cken-cup-worth-38m

People, eh?

PM

BE

500 years old doesn't sound that old.

11:05 am

11:06 am

11:06 am

PM

The Shanghai-based former taxi driver is on a buying binge that has left rivals gasping at auctions as he outbids all comers for ancient scrolls, Tibetan silk embroideries and imperial porcelain. He’s built and filled two museums with more than 2,300 works, including contemporary pieces by Jeff Koons and Yayoi Kusama. In the past year he’s spent more than $115 million picking up such treasures.

PM

http://www.bloombe...udiest-billionaire

undefined

And also say hello to Zoomy Boy

PM

Long time Zoomy...

BE

Yeah, always welcome to see an old-timer return.

11:08 am
BE

So where to begin?

BE

It's a very results-heavy day, so do lodge requests.

BE

FTSE down on miners though. As usual.

11:09 am
BE

FTSE off 0.5%, 31 points, at 6264.

11:10 am
BE

Let me cut to this Barclays sector rejig.

PM

go no then

BE

It's saying that even after an "unprecedented fifth year of underperformance", still don't buy.

11:10 am
BE

Because there's no quick fix to overcapacity + demand deceleration

BE

Here are the recommendations. Brace yourselves.

BE

11:11 am
BE

So, to summarise their thinking here .....

BE

China remains uncallable

BE

(They spend about 20 pages discussing its uncallability)

11:11 am
BE

So pricing will be at marginal cost for the foreseeable

BE

Which is causing valuation dissonance. PEs are high and rising, whereas NPVs aren't

BE

Advice is to switch from BHP to Rio, as the latter has the best looking balance sheet

11:12 am
BE

Continue to buy Glencore on "strong FCF, copper exposure in the short term, and debatable upside on NPV calculations"

BE

But don't go near Anglo American ("negative earnings momentum, balance sheet risk and valuations")

BE

Ditto Vedanta and Kaz "on the basic premise that this is not the time to be holding high risk, leveraged mining stocks".

11:12 am
BE

Here's how the exec summary puts it.

BE

2015 has been another bad year for the sector. The last 5 yrs have now been the worst
period of performance since 1966: Looking forward it is hard to see what might pull the
sector out of its tailspin. A demand shock seems unlikely given the state of China’s
economy, although there are some signs of near term improvement (M2, property starts,
TSF growth). Pinch points in supply/demand are getting pushed back implying marginal
costs will govern pricing for longer. Costs themselves are under negative pressure.
Meanwhile, returns on equity are sub cost of equity following unprecedented
capex/depreciation levels, and net debt as a proportion of EV is at an all time high. Finally
one has to sift through valuations to find metrics that support an investment case. So we
downgrade our sector view to Neutral (we would have reverted to our Negative call of
2013-14 if it weren’t for the recent pick up in some Chinese data, plus sector positioning).

BE

Stock specifics. Only Boliden and a few gold stocks have provided any positive
performance YTD. Rio Tinto screens the best still on valuation/balance sheet strength
so we upgrade to OW. We stick with OW on Glencore (commodity mix, catalyst
expectation, overly negative perception and FCF yield), but remove it as our ‘Top Pick’.
We downgrade BHPB to EW with very little valuation support and stick with AAL and
Vale as UW. We are downgrading the more leveraged Vedanta and Kazakhmys to UW.

11:13 am
BE

Valuations – nothing screening well: PER multiples are virtually redundant due to a
combination of low commodity prices, the highest leverage in history and high D&A
charges following unprecedented levels of capex (imply further impairments to come).
FCF yields are all low single digit or negative on spot (a mild recovery in commodity
pricing next year helps). Dividend yields where paid aren’t believed (other than Rio) and
P/NPVs cannot be trusted.

BE

Commodity prices remain under pressure: Marginal costs remain the driver of
commodity pricing in our view and are under pressure (for instance two of the biggest
copper mines in the world – Escondida and Collahuasi – have 85% lower productivity than
one of the lowest grade mines in the world: Aitik). Iron ore price resilience may well be
tested again too, which worries us given its gone back up to generating 63% of the
sector’s EBIT for 2016. Changes in order of magnitude are: Nickel -18%, oil (Brent) -17%,
copper -11%, aluminium -9%, thermal coal -8%, platinum -7%, iron ore -7% and
platinum -5%. All others are less than 5% moves. .

BE

Earnings remain under pressure: On a weighted average basis, we are cutting the Big 4
earnings by 28% in 2016. For 2016E we downgrade our EPS forecasts as follows: BHP -
31%, Rio -32%, Glencore +2%, AAL -46%, Vale +30%, S32 -35%.

11:14 am
BE

On Glencore, incidentally, it's been volatile even for Glencore over the past couple of days.

PM

Sure has

BE

With nothing obvious driving the intraday volatility. Nickel down yesterday for example, which is negative, but not really the kind of thing people worry about usually.

11:15 am
BE

I'd only note that the recent -- very late reported -- Qatar sales of BG and Shell do suggest some portfolio rebalancing going on.

PM

Does seem to take a while for news to travel from Doha to London

BE

Yeah. See yesterday's session for all the detail of that.

11:16 am
BE

And Qatar has historically been rather tardy with its updates on its Glencore stake

BE

This is all speculation, I underline. It'd be unsurprising to see that QIA has been a seller of Glencore of late. We'll just have to wait until some time in late November to know for sure.

11:17 am
PM

Should mention Lonmin

BE

Of course.

PM

It's fallen 46 per cent since we declared it a "screaming sell."

11:17 am
PM

It's still a screaming sell, id suggest

PM

And im coming round to the idea that the underwriters are actually at risk here

PM

If they get left a stick at 1p, they are not going to shift it at 1p

11:19 am
PM

And there will be a rump, at least, if only because of the number of retail punters that have been playing this thing and are now missing digits

PM

scorchedfingers scorchedfingers scorchedfingers

BE

Hm. It's ridiculously obvious that it's not raising enough money. One has to wonder why Lonmin didn't proceed this with the usual "no value left in the equity if ..." stuff.

11:19 am
PM

Good question

BE

Should've at least drilled the price down to a few pence before the rescue rights, which wouldn't have caused this unseemly rush for the exits.

BE

CIBC saying shareholders should vote no.

11:20 am
BE

Because, sod it. That's their argument.

PM

hahaha

BE

I paraphrase, but only slightly.

11:20 am
PM

And a sound argument that is too

BE

The rights issue will be priced at 1p/share - pushing issued shares
from 587 million to 27.6 billion (+4,600%) and essentially forcing
shareholders to participate. The issue is underwritten by the
syndicate of banks and part-underwritten by the PIC (S.A.
Government Pension Fund and 7.7% shareholder).
Assuming all is lost, is it worth throwing another $400 million in
good money after bad? The answer very much depends on one's
view of metal price direction. At current spot or lower, we don't think
it's worth even trying. By the same token, even just a 10% rise in
the metal price basket from current levels should deliver some 70%
increase in value and (almost) enough cash flow to cover the debt
payback in 2020. Against this though, the downside is much more
geared, with a value loss of 150% on a 10% drop in prices.

BE

ALL this equity issue does is buy time. The same team runs the
same "wait for metals prices" strategy that, given the now
drastically increased risk, could deliver explosive upside... or the last
roll of the dice if prices don't improve.
The risk is still too high and we don't like that investors are being
basically forced into this deal or threatened with total loss. Debt
holders will be highly unlikely to shut the company and place 36,000
people on the street. From a shareholder perspective, it might be
worth pushing the banks to roll over on the current debt, even at
higher interest charges (MUCH better than the current dilution) -
delivering the same bottom-line benefit... buying time!

11:21 am
BE

We foresee good upside if prices improve, but given the massive
initial losses to first reach that base, we believe it may be worth
calling the bluff of the debt holders. We would vote against the
issue. Including the equity issue drops our price target to
£0.013/share (£0.20/share before, and before the billions of
additional shares), effectively equating to £1.30/share after the
proposed 100-for-1 share consolidation. We maintain our SU rating.

PM

That's a key point about the 36,000 workers

PM

Political leverage over the banks is real here

11:22 am
PM

Very real

BE

Yup. The simple reading here is that the shares should trade at the TERP or 1.32p.

BE

"of" not "or" .... But really, it needs a discount on that.

11:23 am
BE

Because it's still cashflow negative

BE

And the risks -- BEE mentioned on the right, and I don't claim any expertise on South African politics -- are unquantifiable.

BE

Sell while you still can. sell sell sell sell sell sell sell sell sell sell sell

11:24 am
Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 9.82, down 3.43 (-25.89%), High: 11.50, Low: 9.50, Volume: 16.66m
PM

hehehe

PM

ML recommendation: "Run"

11:24 am
BE

Deutsche says we're wrong to even consider this a rescue rights. It's a backdoor IPO.

PM

??

BE

I'll let them explain.

11:25 am
BE

Lonmin's underwritten $407m rights issue is at a 94% discount (GBp1ps), a de
facto IPO in our view: existing sh/holdings will be 98% diluted. A successful
issue means creditors will extend to 2020 US$370m of facilities due to expire
H1CY16. The EGM is on 19 November 2015, 5 resolutions will be voted (2
special, requiring 75%). Our valn, with a rising price deck, is $1.3bn (significant
upside), but our NPV at spot is negative and our Buy rec. is purely a call on
higher Rand-PGM prices. Following these rights is funding a business which, at
spot, is marginal and will give it up to 3 years of liquidity (DBe). Significant
upside is possible, but approach with caution.

BE

Each right will give an existing shareholder the right to purchase a further 46
Lonmin shares, implying a dilution to existing shareholders who do not follow
their rights of c.98%. PIC (7% shareholder) has sub-underwritten “a material
portion”. HSBC, JP Morgan and Standard Bank are the underwriters.

BE

The market cap plus net cash raised over new shares (587m in issue plus 27bn
to be issued) gives a theoretical ex-rights price (TERP) of SAc29ps / GBp15ps.

11:25 am
BE

successful rights issue provides Lonmin with c.US$450m in liquidity (net
cash proceeds of the rights issue of US$369m add unutilised facilities of
US$86m). Retrenchment costs are $59m and capex for the next three years is
US$430m (US$132/110/188m over FY16/17/18e). Thus, if Lonmin’s cost and
basket price are equal (as was the case in FY15) then available liquidity will be
spent within three years on capex. It is our view that Lonmin needs higher
Rand-PGM prices to have a sustainable business case. If investors vote
through the rights issue it will be on the hope that higher prices arise before
Lonmin runs into liquidity problems again.

BE

We derive our PT using a SOTP DCF (WACC 10% 0.9x NPV) less GBp46ps
contribution to follow rights. We caution that Lonmin’s survival may well
depend on a successful conclusion of the rights issue. We require higher Rand-
PGM prices to obtain a positive valuation for Lonmin.

BE

So: Binary outcome. Higher Rand-PGM prices and it has value.

11:26 am
BE

If not, the cash call only prolongs the inevitable.

BE

Still 9p. sell .

BE

BE

Premier Foods PLC (PFD:LSE): Last: 43.71, up 7.96 (+22.27%), High: 45.00, Low: 39.50, Volume: 5.96m
PM

rocket

11:33 am
BE

Anyway, it's a beat.

BE

H1 EBITA of £50.6m

PM

Interims here: http://www.investe...1511100700061120F/

11:33 am
BE

Consensus was £46-48m

BE

Note, though, the beat's on cost phasing.

BE

A&P mostly.

11:34 am
BE

Management's positive tone seems to be the greater encouragement.

BE

Credit Suisse says ...........

BE

■ Underlying Q2 sales are up 2.4% (1.6% for branded) after 2 years of
declines (we had -1%). Momentum has continued with Q3 branded growth
expected to be "positive". Indeed the group seems sufficiently confident to
set a 1-2% branded growth target for the new year and beyond.
■ Gross margins are up over 300bps with better leverage, benign raw material
costs and more careful trade spend. Margins in "Sweet Treats" are now
expected to be 10% this year (+170bps) – earlier than expected. Marketing
is being re-phased towards the busy Q3 and will be up for the year (down
£2-3m H1), but even the full year expected total A&P spend is nudged up
(from £34-38m to £36-38m).
■ The debt is as expected with the full-year outlook much as we had. The
pension deficit (under IAS accounting) is down to only £33m (higher
discount rates), though this doesn't change the payments that are agreed to
2020 and have a net present value cost of £390m.
■ Our estimates are unchanged but that in itself is a major step forward. This
may be only one quarter , but stability offers significant upside to the shares
in our view.

11:34 am
BE

And UBS

BE

Which now does extremely brief summaries for fund managers who can't bear to read more than three paragraphs about the stocks they're in.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: A positive set of results for Premier: H1 revenues £307m, with H1 branded sales
0.1%, non-branded 10.6%
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Within sweet treats, mgt expects to deliver dd margins a year earlier than previously
expected (11% group ebit). Marketing spend will be higher than prev announced (£36-
38m), which we take as a sign of higher mgt confidence. The pension deficit reduced
sig. £33m (from £212m at the April valuation); although payments are fixed out to
2019. The co. announced a new brand: Paul Hollywood premium baking mixes.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Profit expectations for the year are unchanged, (UBSe FY16 adj. EPS 8.2, cons. 8.2).
The company expects to deliver positive Q3 branded sales growth, with the Q2
delivering 1.6%, the first quarterly increase for 2 years.

11:36 am

11:36 am
PM

The likes of Bisto/Oxo and Mr. Kipling witnessed the first benefits of this work over the last year or so, which is now spreading to Ambrosia, where new premium (‘Deluxe’) lines are set to hit the aisles in calendar 2016 whilst we have had the pleasure of tasting Batchelors new premium soup range, which will also hit the streets next year; we particularly recommend Mediterranean style tomato and red pepper. Additionally, new opportunities are being sought through the Paul Hollywood bakery range, Wallasey’s finest sun-blessed baker, tapping into the strong up-turn in home baking in the UK, assisted by ‘HRH the queen of cakes’, Mary Berry.

PM

PM

11:37 am
BE

Gas Blowback?

PM

Whilst relatively small beer at this stage, we are also pleased to see the traction that Premier is seemingly gaining in international markets, which have been allocated an expanded team to support development. Premier reports that H1 FY2016 sales grew by 22% at constant currency in H1 (38% in Q2) with particular traction in Australasia and Ireland through the Sharwoods and Bisto/Oxo brands respectively. Premier also allude to what may in time be a material listing in the USA for Mr. Kipling (apple, fruit & Mississippi mud pies) in 250 stores this month, albeit given the track record of disappointment from this group over the years we are not yet counting any chickens

BE

11:39 am
BE

Should just note this big Deutsche Bank note on the supermarkets.

BE

BE

"Profits are down but business rates are up," he said in a speech at the Confederation of British Industry's conference. "It is the biggest tax we have and is three times the OECD average."

11:40 am

http://www.bbc.co..../business-34772883

"For every £1 we pay in corporation tax large UK retailers pay £2.31 in rates. It is unsustainable."

BE

11:40 am
BE

Anyway, Deutsche talks pricing power erosion.

BE

You know the routine. Discounters taking share, sales growth at expense of margin, etc.

BE

Downgrading from Buy to Hold
We resume coverage of Tesco post a period of restriction. We downgrade to Hold vs. Buy previously. While maintaining our 2.5% normalised UK margin forecast, we implicitly downgrade our comparable UK margin by 20bps – Dunnhumby, which is no longer being sold, should have added c.20bps. In this note, we outline why we expect Tesco’s UK EBIT margin premium to peers to narrow and hence why our 2.5% forecast is realistic but not “easy”. We see valuation support at these levels but few positive catalysts.
Lower % store ownership limits EBIT margin recovery
The reduction in store ownership from c.70% in 2007 to c.40% in 2014 (before the British Land deal) reduces Tesco’s potential to recover to its historical c.6% UK EBIT margin by 1.5%. The comparable benchmark is 4.5%.
Negative operating leverage is a real challenge
Despite positive LFLs, we think Tesco’s grocery sales ex fuel per selling SQFT are -13% since 2007. We expect negative operating leverage and the increased cost of new business development (online) to drive the EBITDAR margin 2% lower vs. 2007. The majority of our 2016E margin improvement derives from expected gains on commercial gross margin and cost cutting.
Korea disposal has improved the balance sheet but not earnings
Beyond our view of the UK margin, net proceeds from the disposal of S. Korea are less than we had factored into our SOTP. The disposal is even more cash dilutive than earnings dilutive (c.10%), given the low capex budgeted for the country (c.£100m vs. £200m D&A charge). Reduced profitability of the data analytics business, Dunnhumby, also impacts our valuation.

11:41 am
BE

Also downgrades Morrison.

PM

(Actually, TheLeggie I was born in St Mary's hospital, Oldham, Lancs)

BE

Morrisons has the greatest customer overlap with price-led players
MRW’s has the greatest customer overlap with the discounters and Asda, due partially to its geographical exposure and, relatedly, its customer demographic. MRW generates 40% of its sales in Scotland, the NE, Yorkshire and the SW vs. 20% at SBRY’s, 24% at TSCO, 30% at the discounters and 34% at Asda.
Any recovery at Asda is likely to impact Morrisons the most
On 19 Oct, Asda announced a shift back towards its traditional price-focused strategy, to “extend Asda's everyday low price, value-competitive position, further increasing its price advantage over major competitors and strengthening its competitive position against the discounters". We interpret this to mean that the Big 3 are as much a target as the discounters.
Right balance sheet; strong cash flow management
DBe 2015E lease adj. net debt/EBITDAR is 3.3x vs. 4.2x at Sainsbury’s and 5.4x at Tesco. Furthermore, it owns greater than 80% of its store portfolio. Hence its rental bill as % sales is much lower than peers’. Management has outlined a strong cash flow story and so far delivered £650m of a targeted combined £1.6bn from property disposals (£1bn) and working capital inflows (£600m).
But more negative like-for-like sales mean more negative operating leverage
Ultimately however, we forecast MRW to deliver the lowest like-for-like sales growth of the Big 3 – we forecast a compounded -6% LFL at MRW vs. -1% at TSCO and 0% at SBRY over the three years to 2017E. Our positive EBIT margin development from 2014 incorporates c.1% for the elimination of start-up losses related to convenience stores (exited in 15/16) and online, which is due to breakeven in ‘17/18.

11:42 am
BE

And remains on the fence on Sainsbury.

BE

Maintaining Hold recommendation; we think company can defy scepticism
We know of many investors who believe SBRY’s margin performance relative to peers and its own history is unsustainable. We see good reasons for SBRY’s relative margin performance but given the risk of further price investment in 2016, we maintain a Hold rating.
Good geographical and demographic exposure; good product
Sainsbury’s is disproportionately exposed to higher-income London and the south (45% of sales vs. 30% for the market). It’s got a strong convenience business and a strong private label offer.
Better sales performance should help eliminate margin discount to Tesco
Sainsbury’s grocery sales density has declined 8% since 2007 vs. Tesco’s 13%, although by 2017 we expect that difference to narrow to 2%, largely due to the closure of underperforming stores at Tesco. Sainsbury’s total grocery sales are +26% since 2007 vs. +17% at Tesco UK. By 2017, we expect that difference to expand to 15%. We forecast that the combination of better store level sales and better group sales growth supports a better EBITDAR margin development at Sainsbury’s vs. Tesco over the decade from 2007 to 2017E.
Liquidity improved by recent hybrid bonds but extreme events still present risk
DBe 2015 lease-adjusted net debt/EBITDAR is 4.2x or 3.9x ex the £500m hybrid bonds. Ex the hybrids, net debt is under £2bn and we forecast SBRY to generate c.£300m of sustainable free cash flow out of which it pays a dividend of c.50% of earnings. However, if margins fall more than we forecast (DBe 23% below consensus 2017E EBIT), the dividend could come under pressure.

BE

So that's that.

11:42 am

Total Q3 external revenue rose by 19% to £689m (MSe +15% to £667m)
ITV Family NAR up 6% ytd and +8% in Q3, Online better than expected up
29% after 9m.
ITV Family NAR expected at 5% plus for the year ( we are at 5.3%)
October is up 7%, November flat and December +4% ( MSe +4%, +2%, +2%)
giving Q3 up 3% ( MSe +2.7%).
Online, Pay & Interactive performing well: We had thought revenue growth
would begin to slow down as ITV reached the anniversary of its Encore deal
with Sky but in fact growth after 9m speeded up to 29% vs 27% at H1. with
strong performances in pay and advertising.

BE

Studios strong: Organic growth in Studios was 9% after 9m. It was 8% at H1.
ITV believes it has a strong pipeline of new drama including Beowulf, Jericho,
Victoria , Tutankhamun and Poldark for 2016.
Big improvement in viewing – ITV Family -3% after 9m (was -4% at H1) and
ITV1 -3% ( was -7%) helped by the Rugby World Cup and despite the X Factor.
ITV believes that there is a good underlying improvement in soaps and
daytime that should maintain this improvement.
Statement encouraging: We will deliver another year of strong double digit
profit growth and the initial outlook for 2016 is encouraging.
The company appears happy with consensus forecasts for 2015 ( we are on
£863m EBITA and 16.2p of eps for 2015 based on 5.3% NAR growth). ITV
believes it is in good shape in advertising, viewing share, schedule and Studios
going into 2016.

BE

Exceptionals and pension: The cash pension cost swill drop by £10m pa
after the most recent review. Exceptionals will be £100m-£105m at year end
but c£85m of this is Talpa acquisition accounting treatment related . This was
highlighted by ITV at the half year.
Year end net debt likely to be around £350m – lower than our £390m
expectation . We think ITV is likely to repeat the 6.25p special dividend at the
full year stage.

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 246.16, down 12.94 (-5.00%), High: 249.80, Low: 236.00, Volume: 1.45m
11:57 am
BE

Deutsche downgrade

BE

Power price crunch becoming increasingly severe
Capacity concerns have been in focus over the last week, with National Grid's NISM signaling a tightening UK power market. However, weakening gas prices have driven a further material leg down in UK power prices which is likely to heighten the pressure on Drax's earnings and cashflows. We may see a capacity driven bounce in power prices, although in the medium-term we expect more LNG exports from the US to add to the pressure on gas prices. The shares have rallied by c.10% over the last month and now look expensive. We downgrade to Sell with an unchanged 220p/share target price.

Market pressures mounting
Drax has executed well on the parts of its biomass conversion strategy within its control. However, the company is suffering from low power prices and regulatory challenges. The EU state aid process is still ongoing for its fixed price biomass contract, leaving all of its units market exposed. Power prices have weakened by 5-10% over the last month alone, with gas prices dropping by greater than 10%. Our unchanged estimates assume a c.15% improvement in UK power prices versus forwards, as medium-term gas prices rise and the power market tightens, although the shares now look expensive even on this basis.
Financial projections: state aid approval and power prices key uncertainties
We forecast Drax making little in earnings over 2016-18, although we still forecast positive free cashflow of greater than 20p/share p.a. as capex spend moderates. Changes in power prices and the outcome of the state aid process for Drax’s fixed price contract could each have a significant impact on our estimates. If the EU approves the contract at the original strike price, power prices rise strongly, and/or Drax announces a significant cost cutting programme this could lift our estimates. If power prices remain in-line with current forwards or the fixed price contract is not approved, the squeeze could be more severe.

220p/share target price unchanged; downgrade to Sell; risks
We leave our DCF based target price unchanged at 220p, although the rally in the share price over the last month, and drop in UK power prices, makes us worry more about potential downside scenarios. Our DCF based valuation assumes Drax converts three of its six units to biomass with two operating under the RO and one under a CfD (with a contract price of GBP95/MWh real). The main upside risks are higher UK power prices, positive regulatory news, or cost cutting. If Drax secured its fixed price contract at the original strike price this could add 90/share to our valuation.

12:00 pm
BE

In-line interim results contain several positive developments: LFL revenue
growth accelerated to 4% in Q2; after two years of disappointment,
North American Consumer Services positively surprised; LATAM momentum
improved; and the share buyback has been extended by $200m. M&A will reemerge
in 2016, which may create nervousness amongst some investors, but we
acknowledge that capital discipline has improved under the new CFO.

In-line interims. $2216m EBITA (JEFe $578m), $576m adjusted PBT (JEFe $578m), 42.0c
adjusted EPS (JEFe 41.9c) and a 12.5c dividend (JEFe 12.8c). Organic revenue growth
improved to 4% in Q2 (Q1 3%, JEFe 3%) with the uplift coming mainly from improved
performances in North America Consumer Services and LATAM.

Positive mix from the core. At the divisional level: momentum remained robust in North
American Credit Services with 8% LFL growth in Q2 (Q1 8%, JEFe 8%); after two years
of disappointment, North American Consumer Services positively surprised with -5% LFL
growth (Q1 -10%, JEFe -10%); and LATAM’s 6% LFL growth also beat expectations (Q1 7%,
JEFe 5%).

FCF dynamics remain appealing. 95% OpFCF conversion is in line with 95%+ guidance
and ND/EBITDA was 2.1x (JEFe 2.0x). Cash tax jumped to $103m (1H15: $62m) and to 76%
of P&L tax (1H15: 42%), which we think was due to phasing.

Buyback extended by $200m; More M&A likely in 2016. In our 4 November note,
we formally modelled a further $800m buyback next year after completion of the current
$600m programme given another year of strong FCF generation and $164m disposals
proceeds. With these results, Experian has extended the repurchase by $200m (more rapid
than expected) but, having spoken with management, we understand that utilisation of
the remaining c$600m surplus capital may include M&A. We raised this possibility in
our preview note (the industry has been highly active recently and Experian may feel the
need to respond) and have mixed feelings given the value-creation debate following the
41st parameter and Passport acquisitions, but we acknowledge that capital discipline has
improved under the new CFO.

Consensus EPS estimates are likely to remain unchanged. Outlook comments are
unchanged in tone from the July IMS and consequently consensus estimates are likely to
remain unchanged today. “We expect organic revenue growth to be in the mid-single digit
range, to deliver stable margins and to see further progress in Benchmark earnings per
share”.

Reiterate Buy rating. The shares trade on 17.8x CY16F EPS and our 1340p price target
is based on a 22x prospective PE multiple, at the top of the 7-21x range, justified by the
introduction of a more shareholder value focused strategy. At this level, the shares would
trade on a 5.5% FCF yield.
